title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [4–5 December 1863]
text: 5 Dec. 18 '631fridayFriday nightMy dear Walti write to night some of the particulars of Andrews death he failed from the time on the morning you left had very bad turnesturns and would then revive and be better that night you left i was there and likewise mary he was very restless and did not want mary to leave him i stayed late the 2 young men that came to watch he told mary he was dying and he could not dyedie with them there they insisted on my coming home i came and mary stayed untilluntil late and she came and left nancy and them to take care of him wendsdayWednesday morning she went round he was very bad and sent the children here i went again and marthe went he wanted her to come she was there nearly all day only came home to nurse the baby when she or mary went to come away he would beconbeckon for them too him that they would come back he wanted to be moovedmoved from the lounge to the chair he wanted mothersmother's rocking chair poor soul he died in it wendsdayWednesday night martha was there till late then she came home and mary and Jeffy staidstayed all night wensdayWednesday he wanted to see Jeffy marthe went to the office for him he came and stayed till toward night and came home and had some tea i went again in the evening and came back for to see to the children as i said before and martha and jeffy went this was wendsdayWednesday night they had to fan him all night and bathe him in brandy nance went to bed when she came out in the morning she brought such a smell that Jeffy got sick and had to come home being up all night and shortly after mary came bringing georgey besmeard from head to foot mary said she could not go again the smell and her throat being so bad so i sent jess around till they had their breakfast Jeffy and mary thought he could be moved round here we sent for the doctor he went around to see and came back and said he thought we might but we must doodo it very soon mat went round behind the doctor and staidstayed till he came and told us we could he said he would probably live untilluntil 10 oclocko'clock that night this was thursdayThursday morning mary went back and Jeff and mrs brown when the doctor spoke of it nancy made a great adueado said you shant have him he belongs to me he said he wished he could dyedie now i suppose it hurt him mrs brown came for me i went before i got there mary said he would look around she asked him if it was mother he wanted he moovedmoved his head i am very glad we didentdidn't doodo any thing about moovingmoving him i am thankful we was all there he died like any one going to sleep without a struggle sensible to the last just before he died he turned his head and looked at your and georges pictures for some time and then shut his eyes god grant i may never witness another) he seemed as if he was satisfied that we were all around him he drank without choakingchoking before he died he was laid out there and brought here last night and lays in mrs browns room without wacheswatches is to be buried to morrow at 2 oclocko'clock mary has gone away this afternoon he looks very natural his friends is all dooingdoing very good Cornell in particular i ordered three carriages and cornell will send one for her and the children he is laid in a frock coat of Georges and vest and every thing very respectful plate on his coffin with his age and name Jeffy will write the rest i am composed and calm would not wish him back to suffer poor soul i hope he is at rest2i have not heard from George since you left i wish i could) write to hannah walter tell her if she could have seen the sufferings of her poor brother she would be thankfullthankful he was out of his agony) write to me walter as soon as you can if i best take money from the bank to pay the expencesexpenses i told the undertaker i would settle it in the course of 2 weeks) one thing more i must say mrs brown could not be kinder than she is i shall always respect her for her great kindness in our affliction 3what i am going to write i would say nothing only i think Jeffy will last night marthe sent Jess around with nancy tea and seeing his brothers corpscorpse seemed to effect him very much he had not ought to been sent he took on very much and looked a little strange when he came back but nothing more seemed to be very sad but this afternoon martha and hattie and sis were down here hattie done something he didentdidn't like he got up and with a vengeance to whip her and marthe forbadforbade him to touch her child there was a scene he called her very bad names and looked very wild for a while i told marthe to go up stairs or not say any thing but she would she began to cry and her back pained her she went up stairs of course jeff had to hear it all in the strongest light i should said nothing about it but jeff said he should write to you to morrow i said Jesse your brother lies up stairs dead he calmed down immediately and is very good natured i think it was going there last night that affected him) write how you are walt and all good night there was a very good little peicepiece in the eagle last night about you Jeffy will i think send it to you this is a packed lettergood bye againyour mother LW Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [4–5 December 1863]
